moves.3. Nf3 g5 4. h4 g4 5. Ne5: Both men are playing to win, attacking without regard to defense.
moves.5... h5 6. Bc4 Nh6 7. d4 d6: A sensible attempt to drive the Knight.
moves.8. Nd3 f3 9. g3: When this game was played in 1868, this was the standard line. The current usual play is 9 PxP B-K2 10 B-K3.
moves.9... f5 10. Nc3 fxe4 11. Nxe4 Nf5 12. Kf: Attempting to blockade the advanced Pawns.
moves.12... Be7 13. Nf4 Rh7 14. Ng6: Down a Pawn, White tries to reclaim the initiative.
moves.14... d5 15. Nxe7 dxe4: Black's K-side Pawns are becoming formidable.
moves.16. Nd5 Be6 17. Bg5: Attacking the Queen. But Bird has a riposte.
moves.17... Bxd5: A brilliant sacrifice to force the K-side Pawns through.
moves.18... e3+ 19. Kg1 Bxc4 20. Bg5 f2+ 21. K: The Pawns will... underpromote. A superb tactical maneuver by Bird.
moves.23. Rhxf1 exf1=N+ 24. Rxf1 Bxf1: Now it's a matter of time. With his huge material and positional advantage, Bird can coast home.
moves.25. Qe1+ Ne7 26. Qxf1 Nbc6 27. d5 Rf7 28: MacDonnell finally gives in to the inevitable and resigns. A sparkling attack by Bird.
